boat.name: Julietta
boat.full_description:
'Julietta' was built in either 1957 or 1959 by Fairey Marine on the river Hamble.  The timber used in her construction is an African hardwood known as Nigerian Cedar, or Agba. Full production of Atalanta started in 1955 and about 200 were built, with profuction ceasing in the late 1960s

She was discovered by her current owner and a friend in 2007 in a field in Cambridgeshire. They were towing her down to Cardiff with a vintage landrover when the landrover engine blew out on the M4 and 'Julietta' finished the trip under tow from the AA. She was in a poor state, with holes in the deck and hull sue to a lot of rot, and delamination of the plywood.

The repair work took much longer than anticipated and was not completed until 2017, when 'Julietta' was put in the water. Unfortunately the stern tube leaked and she was recovered onto the hard. She stayed there until mid 2018 when it was noticed that the mast was rotten. The old mast was removed and a new aluminium mast was sourced and adapted. It was not stepped immediately as the owner decided to investigate converting 'Julietta' to a gunter rig. This has been done to at least one other Atalanta to enable it to cruise the Netherlands canals.

The Coventry Victor 8hp petrol engine was beyong repair and has been replaced with a 15hp Kabuta which has been marinised and adaptated to drive the variable prop gearbox. Not an easy task.
boat.short_description: Julietta as a fine example of an Atalanta, an early trailer sailor designed by Uffa Fox
